quests:
Each "World" file has a quests array, with a challenge to complete with jq.
this is the beginning of your jq journey.

Start by running 'jq --help' on the command line. Look for the example and try 
running it. Save the output of the example by adding '> questlog/00-0.json' to 
the end of the example command.

If you need a hint, run `cat W00-intro.json | jq '.hints[0][0]'` on the command line.

To test your result, run './doquest'

When you're ready to move on, run `jq -r '.quests[1]' W00-intro.json`

Some things to know:

You should output these quests with the "raw" option (i.e. `cat W00-intro.json | jq -r '.quests[1]'`) for better reading and accurate copy/pasting.

The answer will always be the output of the correct jq, written to a file saved under questlog/. Name formatting is WW-Q.json, where WW is the two digit world, and Q is the single digit quest number.

EXAMPLE:
  To read this you performed jq on W00-intro.json. World is 00.
  You accessed the 1st index in the quests array (`.quests[1]`). Quest is 1.
  combined, that's 00-1.json
  (don't forget to use `tee` or redirect output (`> questlog/00-1.json`) to quickly save.
hints:
The result should look something like `echo ___ | jq ___ > questlog/00-0.json` 

Run `cat W00-intro.json | jq '.hints[0][1]' -r` For the next hint.
